noun.description: A soft pear-shaped fruit with sweet dark flesh and many small seeds, eaten fresh or dried.
The deciduous Old World tree or shrub that bears the fig.

examples: he was figged out in the latest modes

phrases: Karla didn't give a fig for Joe's comfort or his state of mind
The child doesn't give a fig about the parent's needs.
Maybe she knows exactly where she is, but she doesn't give a fig about decorum.
I don't give a fig for their constitutional rights.
Shackled by loyalty to his comrades he really doesn't give a fig for the big picture.
origin: Late 17th century (as a verb): variant of obsolete feague liven up (earlier whip); perhaps related to German fegen sweep, thrash; compare with fake. An early sense of the verb was fill the head with nonsense; later (early 19th century) cause (a horse) to be lively and carry its tail well (by applying ginger to its anus); hence smarten up.
